topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.0: System Maintenance

p.u: PROCEDURE FOR GRACEFULLY SHUTTING DOWN AND RECOVERING 2.0 CLOUD

body.p: This section provides a process to enable the powering down, powering up and then recovering all the HCG (Helion Openstack Carrier Grade) cloud components.
The scope of the document is applicable to all the four cloud deployment topologies namely Denver, Sacramento, Tahoe, and Memphis.

Backup Process::Before shutting down the cloud, remember to take a backup:
Make sure you configure the backup.
Backup lifecycle manager data, HOS Controller MySQL database and WR Controller system files using Attis service - these tasks are performed if we encounter any unforeseen failures at a later point in time.
Execute attis commands on HOS controller:

Attis commands that are applicable to ALL the topologies - attis backup --config-id <Config_ID_of_lifecycle manager_Appliance_Data_Backup> attis backup --config-id <Config_ID_of_lifecycle manager_Appliance_opt_files_Backup> attis backup --config-id <Config_ID_of_Cloud_Controller_Appliance_DB_Backup> attis backup --config-id <Config_ID_of_ WR_Appliance_system_files_Backup>

ol.li: Log in to the Horizon dashboard.
Go to Admin —>System —>Inventory —>hosts.
Lock all the WR Compute nodes.
Once they are locked and the availability state is Online then Power off all compute nodes using the drop down menu.
Lock the standby controller node and power off using the dashboard similar to the Compute nodes.
Once the Standby controller and all the Compute nodes are in power off state, and power off active WR controller node using the iLO.The active WR controller node cannot be locked.
Shutdown the workloads in ESX region from Horizon dashboard.
Shutdown compute proxy.
Login to compute proxy VM via Vcenter or SSH from HLM VM.
Stop nova-compute service.
Shutdown the node using shutdown –h now.
Login to VRS Vapps via Vcenter.
Shutdown the node using shutdown –h now.
Login to VSD Integration node from Vcenter and stop VSD service. service vsd stop.
Shutdown the node using shutdown –h now.
Login to iToolbox VM via vcenter.
Stop dhcpd and apache services. service dhcpd stop. service httpd stop
Shutdown the node using shutdown –h now.
Shutdown the ESX hosts either from vsphere client OR from iLO.
Login to Vcenter and shutdown. shutdown –h now.

body.note: In the cluster, your Vcenter should be hosted outside the ESX hosts for the above sequence to work.

'ESX Region' is applicable ONLY if you are using either Sacramento OR Memphis topologies. You need to skip the ‘ESX Region’ power down sequence steps if you are using either Denver, OR Tahoe topologies.

ol.li: Power off VRSG nodes [in case of HA, power off both the VRSG nodes] either from SSH from iLO console.
Login to the DCN controller and bring down the VSC VMs using command virsh shutdown <vsc name>. In case of HA, there will be two DCN controllers and hence there will be two VSC VMs in total.
Power off the 3 HOS controllers after bringing down MySQL cluster in each node as follows.

Stop mysql on all controller nodes
$sudo /etc/init.d/mysql stop

Find the sequence number on all nodes:
$ sudo cat /var/lib/mysql/grastate.dat # GALERA saved state version: 2.1 uuid: 5bd38b4a-70e9-11e4-ad52-7647a787e29a seqno: 1419441 ------> sequence number cert_index:
The seqno may be specified as -1 : $ sudo cat /var/lib/mysql/grastate.dat # GALERA saved stateversion: 2.1 uuid: 5bd38b4a-70e9-11e4-ad52-7647a787e29a seqno: -1 cert_index: In this case run the following command to find the sequence number (mysql service must be stopped to run this)
$ sudo /usr/bin/mysqld_safe --wsrep-recover 141127 12:30:18 mysqld_safe Logging to '/mnt/state/var/log/mysql/error.log'. 141127 12:30:18 mysqld_safe Starting mysqld daemon with databases from /mnt/state/var/lib/mysql/ 141127 12:30:18 mysqld_safe Skipping wsrep-recover for 5bd38b4a-70e9-11e4-ad52-7647a787e29a:1420242 pair 141127 12:30:18 mysqld_safe Assigning 5bd38b4a-70e9-11e4-ad52-7647a787e29a:1420242 to wsrep_start_position ---> 1420242 is the sequence number 141127 12:30:21 mysqld_safe mysqld from pid file /var/run/mysqld/mysqld.pid ended

Shutdown the db from the controller which has the least sequence numbers. In case all the controller nodes have same sequence number. Just power off from controller-3, controller-2 and controller-1 in sequence.
From KVM host, shutdown the VSD VM using command virsh shutdown <vsd name>.
Shutdown the HLM VM using the command virsh shutdown hlm.
Power off KVM/ HLM host node using command shutdown –h now or from iLO.
Shutdown the baremetal compute nodes from either iLO or from the node itself.

Shutdown the baremetal controller node form either iLO or from the node itself. Baremetal region is applicable ONLY to Sacramento topology. Skip the ‘Baremetal Region’ power down sequence steps if you are using either Denver, Tahoe OR Memphis topologies.
Continue with the shutdown sequence of ESX region.

i.u: Powering Up Server Hosting HLM VM and VSD

ol.li: Power on KVM Host from iLO.
Start VSD and HLM VM using commands virsh start hlm and virsh start vsd.
Make sure you can SSH and ping both HLM and VSD VM.

SSH to VSD VM and check the if the services are running fine. Service vsd status.If the service is displayed as a failed status, make sure the server is synced with NTP. Use command ntpstat. If NTP is not synced, wait until the nodes are synced with NTP.If the VSD service fails to start any service like Percona, MySQL, and Jboss, try to start the service manually by command monit start <service_name>. eg: monit start jboss.
Power on the controllers - Check the iLO console to confirm all controllers are rebooted.
Make sure all 3 controllers are accessible [ping /SSH].
Login to all 3 controllers in sequence and check if its synced properly with NTP server using the commands sudo ntpq -p and sudo date.
Check the MySQL sequence number in all controllers with command sudo/usr/bin/mysqld_safe --wsrep-recover.

If the sequence number is same in all controllers, start MySQL cluster in sequence starting from controller 1, 2 and 3:
In controller 1 sudo /etc/init.d/mysql bootstrap-pxc sudo /etc/init.d/mysql start
In Controller 2 :sudo /etc/init.d/mysql start
In Controller 3:sudo /etc/init.d/mysql start
Make sure that RabbitMQ is in sync with the cluster.
Run the command sudo rabbitmqctl cluster_status.
It should display all the three controllers in sync as follows:

Power on DCN host from iLO. SSH to DCN node and start the VSC vm using command virsh start vsc.
The remaining three steps mentioned below (step 10 to step 12) is NOT applicable for Denver topology.
Power on VRS-G node from iLO and make sure its accessible via ping and SSH.
Login to the DCN host and connect to VSC VM using command virsh console vsc.
Login to VSC VM using admin/admin.

Once you are inside VSC VM, execute the following commands to verify VSC and VRS-G:admin display-config show vswitch-controller vsd show vswitch-controller xmpp-server show vswitch-controller vswitches
Sequence 2 : WindRiver or KVM Region
Power on WR controller node using iLO.
Once WR active controller comes up, power on WR standby controller through iLO.
Once the WR standby controller comes ‘online’, unlock them from Edit Host command button drop down.
Login to WR dashboard, power on all the compute nodes and ‘unlock’ them from Edit Host command button drop down.
Power on the Vcenter server.
Power on the ESX servers from iLO OR login to the Vcenter server to power on the ESX servers.
Start the VRS agents VMs from Vcenter [give it ample time to boot up].
Start the itool box VM, vsd, compute proxy VMs in ESX from Vcenter.
Login to the VSD VM and make sure it's synced properly with NTP server using command ntpq –p.

Once it's synced to the NTP server, make sure all services are running fine using command service vsd status OR monit summary. If any of the service is shown as failed OR not monitored, start the same using command monit start <service_name>.
Once the compute proxy powered on, ensure that it's accessible from the HLM VM via ping/ssh.
SSH to compute proxy and make sure that the nova service is running service nova-compute status .
Check and confirm ‘ifconfig’ output has eth0 and eth0.vlanid interfaces where the IP is assigned to the eth0.vlanid interface.
Poweron the baremetal controller node from iLO.
Poweron the baremetal compute nodes from iLO.
